Appearance  Pours a deep brown color with a slight reddish hue. Upon pouring there is a giant off white head. The head is composed of big bubbles, but yet has quite a persistence and lasts for some time. Over time it fades and leaves some very nice lacing.

Smell  The aroma is big in malt and sweetness. The malt is mainly roasty in nature with nice biscuity aromas mixed in. For the sweetness, it is composed largely of a toffee aroma with some lighter dark fruit aromas mixed in.

Taste  A heavy sweet malt favor meets the tongue. It is a bit of roasted malt with some sweet cherry bread. Toward the middle the fruit flavors of some cherry and even a little citrus work their way in mixing well with the nice roasty malt flavor. These flavors persist to the end and finish off the taste by mixing with a light boozy flavor that leaves a very nice warming sweet flavor in the mouth.

Mouthfeel The body of this beer is quite creamy and thick. You can almost chew this one. The carbonation level is just below average and helps to accentuate the nice thick, chewy, creamy body. Mixing the wonderful body and nice carbonation level with the warming feeling that the alcohol brings it makes for an overall very enjoyable mouthfeel.

Overall  This was a nice brew. A nice thick body with some strong sweeter flavors. A very nice sipper with great flavors and a nice feel.

Appearance:
Plum and mahogany with cherry wood highlights. A boisterous tan head fades in rocky clumps and swirls just as foamy and rocky.

Nose:
Cocoa powder, chocolate crisps, and graham crackers. Date and raisin pumpernickel bread. Boozy chewy maraschino cherries in the middle with a tickle of spicy heat in the back. Liquor cherry cordials.

Palate:
Creamy and chewy with pulped and smashed cherries. Tannic apple and plum skins in the finish makes the tongue tingle. Spicy heat in the breath  boozed cherry cordials. Lips are sticky. Candied apples and plums. Sweet smoky chocolate along the sides. Skor bars smoldering over a fire. Dry rustic finish.

Final Thoughts:
With all the spicy boozy rustic notes, I was thinking more of a barrel-aged Alt-bierif that is even possible. There was even a hint of Samichlaus in there. Truly unique and truly delicious.
Bitterness up front, sugar and rum, a bit medicinal, and the alcohol follows it up strongly. A bitter reminder of hops stays on the back of the tongue. The smell is much nicer than the flavor.

Bottle form the long shot packs.  Derf should keep his secret, because this beer was not very good.  Brown color, white head, sweet as all hell.  Fruity, brown sugar, some hops, huge alcohol burn.  Not my favorite beer, thanks but no thanks Derf.

12oz bottle served in a Sam Adams Perfect Pint glass.

A - Pours clear and dark amber in color. 1 finger of tan head.

S - Graham cracker sweetness, yeasty pie dough, dates, caramel covered nuts.

T - Figs, dates, and raisins soaked in alcohol, theres a good amount of spiciness as well. Thin molasses and nutty caramel malts ride the middle of the fruit. Finishes with spicy alcohol bite.

M - Medium body, good carbonation, slick feel, mellow, mellow warmth.

Great job by the home brewer. This one has a very nice nose on it. A good drinker too but not as put together as the aroma. I did like the fruit esters. Well done.

Serving type: bottle

04-06-2012

Rich deep brown coloured body with a hint of toffee, ruby and amber tints and a thinnish tan head. Aroma of alcohol, sugars, caramel, yeast, graham crackers and a bit of pit fruit - nice. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong toasted malt flavour up front with a big metallic bitterness, some caramel, a little yeast and a strong alcohol warmth at the end. Aftertaste shows a lot of complexity with pit fruits, caramel, toasted malt and a bit of spices at the end, but perhaps a bit too much depth and pungency with metal showing through. Overall, a good and relatively complex beer with a solid flavour profile and a good representation of the style. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Total Wine in McLean, Virginia on 01-August-2012 for US$8.99/6 pack, sampled at home in Washington on 30-April-2013.

12 oz. bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a clear brown color with a small beige head.  The aroma is malty, caramel, light chocolate, fruity with citrus notes.  The flavor is moderately sweet, caramel, lightly toasted, citrus notes; medium plus bodied.  A bit bigger than most alts.

Bottle from drabmuh. Thanks Matt.

The beer is copper colored with amber / ruby highlights and a half inch of tan head. The aroma offers candy, sugar, malt - smells sweet. The flavor brings sweet malt, candied fruit, and booze. A bit hot and sweet for my tastes, but I suppose the style calls for this, at least to a certain degree. Some plum and raisin characteristics emerge more as the beer is allowed to warm. Medium bodied with appropriate carbonation. Overall, this was pretty good.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-16-2012

12oz bottle. Hazy deep amber with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of citrus, caramel, chocolate, and earthy. Tastes of earthy, caramel, toffee, chocolate, with some dark fruits. Alcohol well hidden.

Dark browish cloudy pour, thin ring of white head, light lacing  ..... Aroma of caramel malts and light orange with a bitter hoppy citrusy grapefruit bite ... taste is of caramel malts light orange and bitter faded grapefruity hops nice bite with a lingering bitterness ... Warms up well ... Not bad at all abv hidden very well

12 oz. bottle. Pours an amber caramel brown with a foamy tan head. Smells of caramel malt and earthly hops with notes of fruit. Tastes of strong caramel malt with an underlying hop bitterness and alcohol flavor. The flavor balance slowly disappears by the end of the beer with the bitter and alcohol flavors dominating. It still tastes good, but its not perfect. Full bodied and sticky; a little heavy and dry in the finish.
An above-average alt that needs better balancing between the hops and the rest of the palate, but overall is good.

sample from a 12oz bottle, shared by tmoney99. Wow, never had an alt with such high ABV. Clear brown/red color. Little light brown head, dots of lace. Big, rich full body, but not sticky in the finish, very nice. Chewy. Good fruit notes. Little earthy hops. Light sweet taste. Some bitter. Hint of smoke. Tasty stuff.
Bottle to taster (thanks tmoney99).  Looks solid; a semi-transparent brown with thin off-white lacing. Smells malty.  Tastes the same with an average mouthfeel.  Better than I expected.

Appearance:  clear, very dark brown with garnet highlights, short tan head and thick lace ring around the top.   Aroma: slightly boozy, with notes of caramel, syrup, molasses, wet granite, and a bit of earth.   Taste: bready and sweet, with flavors of molasses, a hint of maple syrup, chocolate-covered cherries, leather, wood, and wet leaf.   Finish: sticky, slightly sweet, a bit boozy with mellow, earthy hops trying to balance.   Notes:  Not a huge alt fan, but this was a big, bold, tasty beer.  Not for every day, but enjoyable.
This is pretty good but definitely sticky sweet. It has a sugary character to the body but doesnt taste as strong as it is. Pretty good.

Pours a medium brown color with a light tan head with good lacing. Smells of molasses, brown sugar, caramel and citrus. Tastes  mostly the same as it smells but also has a dark fruit taste and the flavors come out better with a defefinate alcohol presence from the abv. Palate is light and creamy with a dry finish. This is a pretty good beer overall for the style and I enjoyed it

Bottle. Poured a murky brown color with a smaller off white head. Aroma was molasses, brown sugar, malts and syrup. Flavor was some dark fruit, candies, molasses and sugar. Big body. Heavy mouthfeeel. Longer finish. Decent to above average beer.

THOUGHTS: Very nice. Very malty. I havent had many alts, but this is better than I remember the others being. It was easy to drink for the high ABV.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, dark, reddish amber with a large, off-white head that mostly diminished and left good lacing. The aroma had heavy bread, caramel and all sorts of malt; light to moderate herbal, citrus and resin hops; prune; apple; cherry; alcohol; and hints of cola. The initial flavor was moderate to heavily sweet and lightly bitter; while the finish was moderate to heavily sweet and light to moderately bitter with and average to long duration. There was all sorts of malt, tons of malt, caramel, prune, cherry, apples, citrus and resinous hops, something a little rubbery, alcohol, dark bread and a little cola. The medium body was a little oily and then a little dry with soft and lightly tingly carbonation and a lightly alcoholic finish.
Bottle pours dark hazy brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is very nutty with slight phenolic boozyness.  Flavor is big and rich bread malts, lots of caramel and toast with a sweet finish.

12 oz. bottle- Pours clear brown to ruby red with a one finger foamy tan head that reduces to a blanket. The aroma is caramel malt, spicy, toffee. The taste is big on caramel malt, alcoholic, syrupy, the finish is sweet but dry. Decent beer, but not really my style.
Murky brown, with a thin ring o foam. Huge malt aroma - molasses, toasty, and rich. Smooove palate. Very malty. More molasses and toast, perhaps even some rum. Crisp, woody finish.

12 ounce bottle poured an amber redish color, with aromas of malt, over riped fruit, light citrus, and some caramel.  Flavors are the same, heavy malt flavor overall, did not taste like a 9.3% beer that is for sure.

Bottle.  Enjoy before:  08/12.  A clear deep copper/light mahogany pour with a thick and creamy khaki head.  The aroma consists of caramel, spiced apple cider, a rich breadiness, and some mild citrus in the background.  A little vanilla and some woodsiness become apparent as things warm up a bit.  Goes down medium-bodied and fairly smooth.  Gets a tad sticky as it warms.  The taste starts with a good deal of caramel, toffee, apples, and pears.  Estery.  A mildly grainy/bready middle.  A tangy finish with some oranges and touches of zesty citrus rinds.  Hints of grassiness.  A fair amount of spiciness throughout.  The perfect level of warming alcohol that only adds to the complexity of this beer.  Nice work Derf!

beautiful translucent dark red with a creamy tan head. heavy full body with medium-high carbonation.

aroma: rich bready german munich and aromatic malt, caramel, spicy grain, over-ripe fruit, leafy hops, and magic marker alcohol.

taste: rich bready munich malt, spicy tart grain, leafy hop bitterness, fruity esters, and magic marker.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a slightly opaque amber with reddish hues.  Aroma of caramel, nuts, spruce and raisin.  Flavor is toffee, caramel, peat, with hints dark chocolate covered cherries.  A sweet and slightly dry finish.  This is a really good altbier.

Pours cloudy brown with a small tan head, perfect alt/doppel appearance. Aroma is super sweet, syrup, raisin, malt. Flavor is slightly less sweet, but still very syrupy, malty, dark fruit. Palate is quite nice, light carbonation. Overall a nice beer, if a bit on the sweet side. The high alcohol doesnt really show. More of a doppel than an alt, though.

The aroma is fruity, bread, vegetables.  The appearance is opaque red/brown, cream colored head.  The flavor is fruity, bready, slightly boozy.  Like a dopplebock.  Medium/thick in body, creamy.  The finish is pine, grapefruit, lingering.  Very good overall.  Good representation of the style, although this may have crossed the line from altbier to dopplebock.

Big Top Beverage Mart... variety case: Pours a reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma is Eastern European marinated fruits... kind of doppelbockish. Body is ridiculously heavy. Taste is rather sweet. Finish is slightly hoppy and bitter. Lots of fruitiness. This is a hard one to drink. I wish I only had one these rather than 8. Not my thing.

A malty, black licorice flavor profile chased with some fleeting citrus notes and a deep body. Some hoppiness knives through the aforementioned tastes, but its pretty subtle. Prepare for that hanging 9.3% bliss.

Bottle. Poured clear brown color with an average frothy light brown head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Moderate roasted caramel and citrus aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met.

I am a fan of the style but this one was off the mark for me.  There was a nice citrusy zing in the middle being pressed on either sides by a too sweet aroma and taste and on the other side by a really hot alcohol burn.  Poured a medium brown with a nice head but that was the highlight.

Best before August of 2012.

A: A beautiful clear mahogany body shows plenty of lazy carbonation floating towards the huge tan creamy head that forms a plateau as it slowly dissipates leaving a mess on the glass. This is a great looking beer!

S: Whoa this is a sweet malty beer, hints of toffee, and some fruity notes of sweet apple. This is great!

T: Very malty and sweet. This has hints of apples through the sweet caramel, molasses, and toffee body. The end gets a bit thick though and hints at alcohol on the finish that sort of take away from the flavor giving it an edgy finish.

M: Moderately thick with little signs of carbonation.

O: Im not sure how this style is supposed to be, but it reminds me a bit of a dopplebock. This is very malty with hints of fruit and I really enjoy it.
Very good. My least favorite of this Longshot release but great color, maltiness and aroma.

Pours cloudy amber with thin head.  Sweet fruits leap out and blend into molasses. Malted toffee follows. Slight alcohol hints. Very strong. Overall a nice brew. Could probably only drink one but it is enjoyable.

Bottled.  Poured clear reddish-amber with a nice, dark beige head.  The aroma picked up sweet, aged caramel, molasses, and darker fruit with cracked black pepper and earthy accents.. very warm.  The flavor found more of the warm fruit and molasses plus some vanilla bean.. peppery alcohol and earthy accents.. tasty, but a tad too hot.  Medium-bodied and spicy on the palate.. lightly-toasted.. decent feel and flow.

12oz bottle from 2012 mix pack. It poured a clear, deep reddish brown color with persistent beige head and some lace. Nice appearance. Aromas of dark malts, citrusy/spicy hops, peppery yeast phenols, boozy alcohol. Flavor had some residual malt sweetness, grapefruity hops balance, tart and toasty, fairly harsh alcohol notes, some red-wine-like fruitiness and tannins. Medium body and carbonation. Unpleasant, harsh, acidic aftertaste. Maybe I got a bad bottle, but I only wanted a small sample of this one. Ive learned there are very few high-gravity lagers I enjoy. I havent had any classic sticke alts, so I dont know how true-to-style this one was.

Light cola brown; healthy cardboard brown head. Thick with tiny bubbles of carbonation. 

Aroma is cola and heavy toffee and molasses. Nary a hop to be found, or at least none that I can detect. Musty barnyard flavors, but Im digginem. Overwhelmed by sweetness but a dark sweetness. There is a touch of orange rind that creeps up after a few minutes.

Dark sweetness on the front of the tongue; very much like a malty cola. The toffee/molasses comes through in a big way. 

Feels smooth, but chunky. Has a palpable fizz that makes the flavors dance a lil bit. This type of beer is so not my alley, but its getting it done with so many diverse flavors. Its sweet but not saccharine; horsey but not dank. Well done, Fred.

The aroma is sweet and malty with mixed fruit and hops. The appearance is brown with a large head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth.  Alcohol is partially hidden.   Overall a really nice beer.  Best Alt Ive had so far.

5/31/12
bottle at azwine.

auburn brown with a small ow head.

a+f= toasted sugar malt, flowers, mild citrus and a dry minerally finish.

medium bodied and meh

12 oz bottle. Pours clear amber with a medium beige head with decent retention. Aroma is bready, caramelly--all malt. Tastes like a real German altbier. Its malty sweet and a bit meaty. Mouthfeel is syrupy, a bit watery maybe. Well-crafted, but this isnt a favorite style of mine.

Sampled on 7/7/2012. This altbier pours a dark brown color from a 12oz bottle. Small sized beige white head with decent retention and nice lacing. The aroma is caramel, malt, sweet and bready. A medium bodied altbier. The malts are caramel, bready and sweet. The hops are herbal and earthy. Decent carbonation. Nice sweet bready malts. Tastes like a dopple sticke. Hides the alcohol well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

12 oz bottle.  Pours on the dark side of amber, clear with an off-white head.  Ripe red apple and pear aroma, raisin and molasses hints.  Nice full palate, tart apple and caramel with lots of citrusy orange, raisin, hinting at roastiness.  Mmm.  Very satisfying beer.

From bottle. Mild sweet nutty aroma, light winey acidic tang. Caramel and molasses, alcohol. Reminiscent of a dubbel. Dark coppery brown clear with light tan foamy lacing head. Medium heavy body with medium-high carbonation. Starts sweet with molasses, alcohol, plum, and rich malt. Clean finish with sweet tang, topped off with a mild bitterness. Sweet nutty after, kinda like Doppelsticke.
deep amber pour with a cream head.  nose is huge on the malts, caramel, sweet, and sticky.  nice on the palate, sticky malts, toffee, caramel, dough, and bread.

The pour is dark amber in color with an off-white head.  Toasted malt with a surprising hoppiness, mostly citrus peel.  Theres a nice sweetness to the nose and quite a bit of white grape, which I seem to get in most alts.  Some caramel and toffee maltiness, maybe a bit of chocolate, too.  The flavor is a bit boozy, unfortunately.  Some citrus hop flavor, a lot of toasted malt, white grape, and toffee sweetness are also present.  The booze really lasts throughout the entire sip.

12oz bottle.  Unfiltered burgundy-brown.  Foamy beige glass-lacing head,  Sweetish brown chocolate and caramel aroma.  Sort of an odd style,  big, but not too overwhelming.  Very malt centered, and while there is a pinch of hop character, its still very sweet.  A touch one-dimensional, not a beer Id really want a sixpack of.

Copper/brown pour, small head that vanishes quickly.  nuts, spice, raisin in the aroma.  Fig, Darker nuts, raisin, slight pepper, brown sugar in the taste - creamy mouthfeel, lower carbonation.  A bit of an old ale quality to this one.  If it were a regular Sam Adams offering Id buy again.

Bottle 355 ml
Aroma mild frontal creamy character, slight nutty accents. Gentle hop with creamy side end.7-
 Appearance   proper look. Clear amber with darker hue. Medium plus tanned creamy white cap. Fairly presentable.
Flavor and Palate : medium plus bodied. Sticky malts with mild nutty character. Slight peppery hints. Sweeter , heftier rendering of Alt. Good.
Bottle: Strong malty, fruity and potent. Alcohol presence is quite strong which distracts from the other complexities. Food Pairing: Fruitcake.

Bottle. Poured into a .3 l Trumer Pils Stange glass, it kicks up a lot of brownish foam. Big malty smell, in fact a Malt-O-Meal smell, right under the cap. Deep brown color, but till well-filtered. Smell from foamy glass continues creamy, rich caramel malt notes. Foam takes a long time to subside, but of course, as it does, Im feeding it more beer. Taste is big on those caramel malts, with a notes of chocolate, too. And a major thread of molasses. Still, the mouthfeel is rather thin. Perhaps the foam and extra malt/alcohol are holding down the fizziness. Warming alcohol nose as the glass tilts further to the perpendicular. I dont get to a lot of sticke alts, but I believe this one actually takes the style up a notch.

This beer is a clear dark copper-brown color with a medium compact off-white head that diminishes steadily. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel and candy. Medium-bodied with flavors of roasted malt, anise, mild hops and a touch of citrus. The finish is sweet caramel malt with a lightly bitter hops. Above average overall.

7/8/12. 12oz bottle thanks to PorterPounder! Slightly unclear ruby amber pour with a small khaki head. Big alcohol in the nose with a bit of sweetness and burnt caramel. Overly sweet caramel syrup flavor with a bit of a burnt aspect. Not digging it.
Bottle. Pours brown with a tinge of amber. Small off-white frothy head. Smells leafy and coppery. Taste is sweet dark fruits, maple, and leaves.

Bread-like malt and alcohol on the nose.  Clear chestnut with a tan head full of bubbles and remaining long.  Lots of alcohol on the nose pretty much overwhelms the malt.  Thin mouthfeel upfront follows through to some medium yeast mouthfeel at mid-palate.  Alcohol and hops present at the finish.  Pretty disjointed, mostly due to the alcohol.

12 oz. bb Aug 2012. Clear, deep mahogany with a lasting disc of creamy foam. Nose is cocoa, toffee, dates, banana, marshmallow and citrus. Taste is similar, but has more dark toffee and raisin. Peppery citrus zest, some grassy hop, and acidity from the roast are nearly able to tame the big malts when the finish rolls around. Heavy body is smoothly carbonated, a tad sticky, and shows just a hint of the 9.3%.

12 ounce bottle from a mixed 6 pack of the Long Shot winners.  The aroma on this is metallic, and sugary sweet with some hints of molasses, and brown sugar.  Light underlying yeasty fruitiness is also present.  Transparent dark-amber body present with a medium, strong off-yellow head present.  Starts sweet, with some caramel hints, and burnt malts.  Becomes fruity in the middle with estery hints, before this becomes a little spicy and boozy towards the finish.  There is no reason for this beer to be this strong, and it just creates a boozy, sweet, mess.  Lacks subtlety, which is exactly what I want in an altbier or a sticke, or even a doppelsticke.

12oz bottle pours a nice clear amber with deep red ruby hues and thin light colored mocha head of foam. The aroma offers up a mix of red apple, earthy dates and cherries as well as some pears, honey and a dab of caramel. The taste carries the same cherry to red apple to earthy date fruitiness as the nose but drops in a tasty amount of caramel that seems to turn into chocolate and then back to caramel again into the finish with hints of roasted maltiness here and there. This offers up a nice mix of flavors.
Brown in color with a decent off-white head. Aroma is of bread, malt, and booze. Taste is of bread, malt, almonds, cherries, walnuts. Sweet, but quite delicious.

Bottle. Ruby red, brownish, off white head, and clear. The smell is big sweet maltyiness, some fruit, vanilla, maple, nuts. The taste is a sweet, almond, amaretto, cherry, and decent despite the big sweetness.
From a bottle poured an amber color with a fair amount of head.  Sweet malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Bottle.  Pours clear mahogany with an average, creamy light tan head, long retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is dates, plum, and fig esters, cookie and caramel malt with faint spicy hops.  Flavor is sweet malt, light hops and bitterness, dark fruits and a dry finish.  Full body and medium carbonation.

You love it or you hate it, but its fun trying all of the longshots. A brown coloured body, it sweet and malty and rich, with a dry finish.
Thats for bringing John.

Pours a clear dark brown under a small off-white head.
Fragrant aroma of sweet malt with a touch of hops.
Lightly sweet start with a soft dry finish. 
Very nicely done.

Picked up the Longshot series from BevMo in Mission Valley, San Diego, Calif. Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. About 2 ½ fingers of head. Color was a malty reddish brown. Heavy tan lacing on the top that had average retention. 

Lots of different flavors on the nose that came together nicely at the end. Got the malts up front that reminded me a bit of a Rogue Dead Ale or a more wintery beer. Newcastle comes to mind quickly. Toffee, caramel, light chocolate and some candy. 

The taste was a bit different than the smell and what I was expecting. Basically an even thicker, maltier version of the smell. Malty is the theme of this beer. Toffee, caramel, light chocolate, light coffee and a bit of roasty nuts. 

Medium-to-full body. Creamy, sticky texture. Below average carbonation. Dirty, grimy, smooth finish. 

Good first beer for me from this six-pack (two beers each of different kinds). Like I said earlier, malts dominates this beer. Very strong and I already feel it about ¾ of the way down through a pint.

A good beer.  Very malty in that German sort of way.  Orange and bready notes.  A little bit of lingering funk coats your mouth on the end, not unpleasant, but it does make this beer more filling than thirst quenching.

the first thing to do is too drink this nice and warm. its got a great balance of strength and flavor. highly malty with a touch of nuttiness and not too bad on the hop front.  lots of tasty caramel. for the lazy day
Dark, clear, orange tinge.  Modest head, minimal lacing, off white.  Nose is toffee, brown sugar.  Taste is malty, graham crackers.  Enjoyable rendition of the style I was introduced to in Bonn.

Deep copper/brown with a solid medium tan head.  Big malt nose with a slight whiff of alcohol?  Cereal malt taste.  Sweet cereal finish with some weak orange and alcohol mixed in.  Moderately smooth until the warming alcohol kicks in at the finish.  Almost tastes a bit thin though.
The aroma is sweet and malty with mixed fruit and hops. The appearance is brown with a large head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall a really nice beer.

A - Pours a fairly clear mahogany-brown color with a finger of frothy tannish head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some thick lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of sweet bready malts with a bit caramelized malts, some grapefruit and citrus hops, a bit of dark fruit, and some yeast.

T - Starts off with some sweet bready malts with some grapefruit and citrus hops and just a touch of bitterness. Through the middle, some light caramelized malt flavor comes through with some dark fruit and biscuit. The finish is a mix of sweet bready malts, with some caramelized and dark fruit sweetness and a bit of yeast and booze.

M - Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth and slightly thick with a warming and sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. The 9.3% abv is fairly well hidden and the beer very nicely balanced from start to end.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, thanks Aaron! Dark reddish brown, thin off white head, aroma brought notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, hints of red grape, dark fruits, toffee, caramel notes, touch of earth and slight spice, anise notes peek in there as well.  Taste is sweet toffee, caramel, dark fruits with raisin, grape, some cocoa, hints of biscuit, finishing fairly sweet, a bit sticky.

bottled pours copper color, very thin head aromas ofmolasses, brown sugar, and raisin.  flavor has a lot of malt sweetness and matches the aromas.  medium bodied.  i dont taste alcohol which is nice in a beer with this much alcohol. finishes with a long malty sweetness. decent beer, good kick

I thought this was pretty good. I found it necessary to keep reminding myself, "this is an alt, this is an alt". On that level, its very good--compared to most alts, which usually bore to tears with a simple bread/caramel malt thing. The alcohol is big here, but that is reasonably well restrained. What was weird about it, as I alluded to already, is that with its dark brown body, moderately vibrant carbonation, and rich malty notes, my brain told me that the beer in my glass is a Belgian dubbel. But if you think that way, it will disappoint, because the fruitiness is too subtle, the sweetness isnt anything like a candi sugar sweetness, and it lacks some of the depth in the malts. Its a big German alt, and on its own terms its quite good. Bottle.

Pours dark crimson, minimal head. Smell is red fruity, a bit malty, powerful. Taste is red fruit, cherry, raspberry, and a bit of alcohol, much like a barley wine. Sipper. Probably the best of the three.
Loved it malty with a hint of hops and extremely smooth. Want a six pack please

Homebrewers are wont to take classic styles and bugger them all up by making them too big or otherwise stupid. Thankfully, this is not one of those brews. It delivers exactly what it says, which is a beer relatively true to the sticke alt style but incredibly enormous. It is a slow sipper w/ the malt profile of an alt w/ complex earthy and nutty tones .I might normally complain this is too sweet but the sweetness does at least work well w/ the heavy fruity and cherry notes and kind of lends a sherry-like quality. I thought this concept would be an abomination unto man but its actually pretty damn good.

12 oz. bottle from Berts Better Beers. Copper color, very thin head. Light spotty lace down the side. The aroma was sweet and sugary with notes of molasses, brown sugar, and raisin. The flavor has a lot of malt sweetness and matches the aromas. I dont mind sweeter beers however this one doesnt get me real excited. People who like malt should enjoy this. Finish is cloying. Medium body. ABV hidden well. A very nice longshot six pack over all.

Nice garnet puor with a big tan head.  Aroma is sweet and malty.  Flavor was quite surprising.  Nearly full bodied.  Initial impression is of caramel, orange and dark fruit with sugary sweet overtones.  Towards the finish there is a long and lingering spicy character.  The alcohol is there but the spice and citrus hide it.  This was a nice surprise... Im a homebrewer and this one must have been difficult to pull off.

This alt pours a gorgeous red-brown ruby. The head is a healthy 2 figers in a tulip.  The aroma, which is way better a little warmer, continues until it hits the  tongue. There is good bitter-malt balance. I suppose experts of German beers could better comment on the malt varieties but they are sweet candy-ish to me. Very smooth on the tongue and throat for 9.3 % . Very tasty for a strong alt bier.

Clear copper with a medium tan head that fades moderately.  Aroma of toffee, dark fruits, sugar and a touch of ginger.  Taste is sweet with toffee, dark fruit, ginger, bready malts and some spices as well.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $9.99/6-pack. A little too malty & sweet.

Pours a medium amber color with a tan head and some lacing. It has a strong caramel aroma with hint of hop citrus. The flavor is very malty, but not too sweet, with some hops in the background and a smooth, sweet finish.

Aroma of orange peels, maple and pine tar. Clear dark brown like a doppelbock. Very sweet malt taste that heads towards cough syrup flavor in a hurry as it warms. Drink it in an iced glass. Body is heavy with alcohol, not too thick, and overall drinkable, at least in small quantity. 12oz. Bottle given by Dano le Dano. Best Sam Adams that I have had in a long time. Poured dark copper with a medium white head. Lots of lacing. Aroma is nice, booze and orange mixed with syrup. Taste starts with a sweet malty taste and finishes with a bit of bitter orange and alcohol. It is relatively smooth for the abv.  Its a big beer for Sam Adams and I realize it was a longshot competition beer but nonetheless I am impressed.  Well done Derf
Too boozy and sweet! Lots of malt and rich body. Dark brown, almost black clear color. IMO, hops were lost.

Bottle. Pours with a clear deep bronze hued body with a small tan head that fades. Aromas are on the sweet side of things with caramel, malty, nutty, light fruit, citrus. Flavors are sweet, malty, nutty, and hot with alcohol. Medium bubbles, full bodied, a bit big tasting.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a very dark brown color with orange highlights and a medium sized foamy tan head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was sweet and tangy with notes of molasses, brown sugar, plum and cola. The flavor was molasses, caramel, cola, wood, nut, cherry, plum, toffee and tobacco. The finish was long and malty with lingering molasses, cola and cherry. Moderately full bodied. The alcohol was well hidden. Solid.

Bottle...  Poured deep, ruby, maroon with a thin head.  Ultimately this was very sweet beer.  I thought it was dimensional and palate mostly got worth malt and sweetness.  Some caramel candied sweetness.  Did I say it was sweet?
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a small frothy beige head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is bready malt and caramel. Thick mouthfeel with a rich malt and bitter hop with sweet finish. A good alt.

Strong, malty aroma has a firm and somewhat sugary overtone of horehound and molasses. It pours a clear, dark, bubbly cola brown with a very thick, fine-bubbled, pale tan head that leaves some good lacing. Flavor has a malty core and strong notes of brown sugar and horehound, heavy on the sweetness - maybe a tad or two too heavy. The undertone of hop bitterness and the alcohol nip do not quite balance the sweetness. Subtle citrus hints come through as well. Texture has decent body and fizz, and is a bit sticky. Good one, but next time maybe ease up on the sugar?
Malt bomb that grew too sweet for me too quickly.  Tons of sweet malt, not that much body and a sugary finish.  Not for me
Super sweet... with a slight sour hint.  Has a syrup taste.  Light aroma.  Its not bad, but not on my list to brew either.

Pours a deep amber, big fluffy light  brown head. Aroma of prunes, orange, brown sugar, raw danish dough. Full bodied, viscous, sticky. Bottle. Clear reddish amber with small head. Aroma of spicy floral and fragrant hops, sweet dough, some grain, and a hint of caramelized malt. Flavor is a touch cloying and hot, with some resinous hops and sweet, sticky malt. The flavor profile lacks balance...

The beer pours a medium brown color with a huge off-white/tan head. The aroma is toffee and biscuit malt, with a sugary smell that resembles Bazooka bubblegum. The flavor has a lot of malt sweetness, with some strong toffee and caramel notes. There is also a lot of sugary sweetness, with the bubblegum notes once again present. Pours a frothy brown which changes to a darker brown with red highlights...tall, steady, tan head.
Scent is a riot of sweet fruits, caramel, sugar...
Taste is very sweet, rich malt,toasted bread, fruit.
This is a very busy beer.  Alcohol stands up towards the finish.  Marvelous...though the smoothness fades some at the end

Poured a dark brown color with a slight read.  Aroma is slightly skunky with some light fruit.  Some slightly grainy notes, but not much else in the aroma. Overall its a little strange but definitely interesting.

Bottle thanks to Dmac. Pours out an interesting rootbeer color with a small white head. Aroma is of lots of dried sweet fruits, black cherries, some light citrus hop bitterness on the end. Taste is sweet fruits, cherry, light grains, caramel, and a light hop bite. Overall the sweetness is a little much to make this a really great beer. Good none the less.
Pours an amber color with an off white head.  Taste is a bit sweet.  Some caramel and brown sugar tastes.  Pretty creamy and smooth.  Nice finish.

Bottle. Pours copper with a beige head. Light malty sweet aroma with earthy and floral hops. The flavor is well balanced, with caramel malts, bread, flowery hops, and light sweet fruity notes. Good stuff.

Aroma- malt forward, caramel, toffee, vanilla, booze
Appearance- dark brown, dank, slightly unappealing
Taste- very malty upfront, clean middle, complex finish with a hop presence and some unidentifiable flavors
Palate- very full, quite nice mouthfeel

12 oz bottle. Clear dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma of fruity plums, caramel and toffee. Flavor is lots of sweet dark caramel malt some light bitter hops and a bit of alcohol warming. Medium body with mild carbonation and a syrupy mouth feel. This is really sweet, lots of caramel and toffee dominate.
355ml bottle from knightly spirits, FL VC # 15. deep reddish brown. hot alcohol nose. brash and young tasting. this one needs some age. to filtered and to sweet.

From the bottle it pours a clear deep mahogany color supporting short- lived tan head. The nose is candied fruit and yeast. The taste is complex. Somewhat sweet up front (malts) with a nod to the hops in the middle and a nice clean finish. There is also an appealing spicy bitter aftertaste. The mouthfeel is medium-to-full with just the right amount of carbonation. A good beer.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of caramel, candied fruits, toasted cereal malts and citrus.  Deep dark brown/ruby hue with an average off-white head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is very sweet and lightly bitter.  Palate is full bodied, average carbonation and clean shorter finish.  Overall a decent brew thats good all around.

Pours a copper-orange color with a massively large, off-white head.  Head takes some time to settle, leaving a good amount of lacing.  Restrained aroma of grapefruit mingled with lemongrass. Pours dark red almost violet with beige head. Smells of plums and raisins with a little alcohol. Tastes about the same quite a bit of alcohol burn. Mouthfeel is creamy.
Bottle. Mahogony beer with a dark cream head. Toffee and light spice aroma. Toffee and light grapefruit flavor with light earth. Medium bodied. Toffee and earth lingers with light grapefruit.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a rusty amber. A thick finger-width beige head on top. Aromas of alcohol, caramel, gingerbread. Firm mouthfeel with a slick finish. Flavors of sweet candy malts - toffee, caramel, brown sugar, syrup. Decent beer, but a little on the sweet side, so not one I could revisit often.
Amber pour with a light tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Taste is sweet, fruity hops. leaves a  nice sweet malty aftertaste. Little cream. Nice lacing.
some spicy character from the hops and the yeast. Residual malt sweetness. high abv drinks very smooth

Bottle from Total Wine. Pours tan with no head. The nose is strong with soy sauce added to a mild vinegar solution. Tastes include biscuit, cereal, and astringent alcohol in the finish. Thin/medium body and low carbonation. Not bad. This isnt one of my preferred styles, but this was enjoyable as it warmed closer to room temperature.

Appealing burgundy/brown in color, very clear, pretty thick slightly tan head.  Nice looking brew.  Very good aroma highlighted by notes of booze, toffee, plum, raisin.  Nicely balanced.  Wow, taste is even better!  More of the same from the nose; very flavorful.  Thick and viscous on the palate, low carbonation.  Quite a nice surprise all around here!  Very reminiscent of a belgian quad minus the yeast and spice.  Fantastic beer!

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling.  It pours a deep tea like color with a small but lasting head of off white foam.  The nose is very malty and sweet.  A bit of dark caramel, wood, and green hops in the nose.  The flavor is bready and thick with notes of caramel, citrus rind, slight prune, and a wood.  Full bodied with prickly carbonation and a slightly bitter finish.  The alcohol is pretty obvious.  Not bad.

deep reddish brown, but very clear. minimal head. smells of roasted malt and caramel. strong alcohol impact to the tastebuds. theres some good flavor there, but theres also a cough syrup flavor that i cant get past. if it were less boozy, id definitely like it better.

From a "Longshot" variety 6-pack. Dark amber pour into thick, foamy tan head that slowly dissipates into a sticky, melting curtain of lacing and a ring of foamy bubbles. Aroma of malty caramel, tangy citrus, and toasty nut bread. Initial flavor of sweet caramel, yeasty biscuit and malty citrus that fades into a buttery, piney, and slightly boozy finish.

It poured a dark red color with a small tan head. The aroma was malty with chocolate, caramel, some raisin, and a hint of citrus. The taste was  sweet with some alcohol lingering in the finish.  A very good altbier.
Aroma of citrus hops and alcohol. Ruby gem brown appearance with a thin head. In contrast to the aroma the taste is creamy, malts, yeast - balanced by bitter orange aftertaste. Nice beer.
Pours chestnut brown with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of molasses,caramel, and dark fruit.  Molasses,toffee flavor with dark fruit.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Nice beer.
I appreciate the high alcohol content, but the awful taste, goofy name, and silly picture of the dude on the bottle mostly turns me off.

4.0 A: Deep amber/brown color. Two fingers of creamy beige head. Retention is average and a small ring of lacing is left.

sweet with caramel and a nice citrus hop character.A note or two of pine IT IS malty with some alcohol. Moderate body and a nice caramel color. Good aroma of fruit and hop. satisfying.

This beaut fell into a snifter with a deep read body and sea-foam head. Aromas were sugary sweet... LOTS of toffee, cherries, honey and alcohol. The taste... well it was like a rum soaked sticky bun with little hop sprinkles on top. This beer was very boozy and malty, hitting you pretty hard after you finish it. Thank you OmegaX for this unusual Sam Adams brew.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful deep brown that shines bright red when held up to the light and supports a large, dense head.  Aromas are a very nice blast of bananas and cloves with a sweet brown sugar backbone.  Flavor is a different story and I must admit I was drawn in by the aromas and now am pretty put off by the flavor.  It is maple syrup and brown sugar sticky and then it gives to an odd banana thing that has a medicinal edge to it before an oddly orange-flavored finish.  Im not quite sure what it is about Alts that puts me off, but there always seems to be some sort of metallic/medicinal edge to them that pushes me away.  Kind of like sucking on a penny or something.  This beer is just like that.

text: Dark red pout with almost no head.  Caramel malt aroma along with some roasted malt and a little chocolate.  Taste is very malty and flavorful.  Sticky mouthfeel that lingers a while and a little tartness on the finish.  A slight alcohol burn too.  Very tasty beer.

12 oz. bottle from BevMo - Pours a clear deep mahogany color with a 3/4 finger thick light tan head.  Very light lacing.  Aroma is caramel malt and esters.  Flavor is also caramel malt and fruit.  Finish is borderline cloying.  just not a fan of this style.  Medium body.  Worth a try.

12oz bottle from Central Market. Im no altbier expert but this seemed nice overall. Definitely big malt sweetness and just a hint of alcohol in the finish. Honestly didnt get much from the hops but I think it was fine overall.

Brown color, tannish head.  Aroma of dried fruits, toffee, vanilla, bready notes, some herbal hop notes. Flavor is sweet and lightly hoppy, some sweet bready notes, toffee, and overall this one is really nice.  Better than I expected.

Woah. Didnt expect this to be so nice. Pour is dark brown with a fluffy tan head and sudsy lacing. Nose is BIG toffee and caramel. Light bready notes with tons of sweet malt. Slight citrus hops. I couldnt believe how easy this was to drink at the 9.3% abv. Very well hidden. Smooth as anything but still creamy in texture. There is a ton of caramel and toffee notes with some light dark fruit and some subtle hops in the back ground. Notes of orange also. Some light grain and a sweet, malt backbone. I would have mistaken this for a quad if I didnt know any better. Excellent beer.

Bottle. Dark ruby-brown with a medium, foamy tan head. Big caramel, sweet malt, soft spicy hops, and toasted grains. Dark bread, toasted malt, caramel, sweet malt, faint fruit notes and spicy hops. Body is medium-full and rather chewy with a moderate, creamy, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more spicy hops, light citrus, dark bready notes, caramel, sweet malt and burnt biscuit.

Bottle: The aroma consists of brown sugar, chocolate, caramel, oranges, and alcohol. It pours a dark brown with some orange transparency and a small khaki headthat quickly fades to a thin film. The flavor starts with brown sugar and caramel. Theres some chocolate in the background. The finish has some light fruit notes, oranges, and a touch of alcohol. Its medium bodied with moderate carbonation.

12oz bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a dark amber with about a finger of very light tan head. Aroma of caramel, toast and grapefruit. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Caramel and citrus with a little grapefruit. Full bodied with a thick texture. Lively carbonation and a very long finish. Overall, not bad at all. Ill gladly drink the 2nd beer that came in the mixed pack.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, light dark ripe fruit, light caramel, and some brown sugar.  Poured deep amber/brown/deep orange in color with a small, creamy, dense, tan head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Sparkling.  Good lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet, but also just off.  Tastes of malt, light caramel, vegetables, and garbage.  Medium body.  Slick, then dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, vegetable, garbage finish is medium sweet, lightly bitter, and dry.  9.3%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Bottle. Red brown pour with a medium tan head. Fresh German hops and caramel on the nose. Flavors of toffee, candi, and a sticky sweet finish that ends with a zing of back of the tongue bitterness. Could stand a little more carbonation but overall a good offering from the Longshot series.

12oz bottle poured into snifter. Always interested in trying these Longshot  beers for some reasons. This was very malty, both in the flavor and aroma, but the ABV is masked extremely well. Very easy  to drink.
Dark caramel like brown in color with an off white head. Sweet malty flavor with caramel and orange leading to a nice, smooth finish. Very full, but not thick.

Clear ruby-brown with a puffy beige head and a fair amount of lacing. Aroma of caramel, toast, and a little citrus. The taste is rich and malty; sweet, mildly bitter, with a bit of alcohol. Full bodied and smooth with a warm booziness. Definitely the heaviest alt that Ive tried. I certainly wasnt expecting this.

12oz bottle, LongShot 6pk, Vintage 2012. Dark copper color.  Tall foam, light tan color.  Huge aroma.  Heavy dark malt, toasted brown syrup.  Big malty nose with loads of toffee.  Loads of dark fruits, dark malt syrup, heavy date sugar flavors up front.  Earthy, leather, toasted caramel and toffee characters in the end.  Some hidden citrus.  Well balanced flavor.  Bitterness is a bit harsh in the end on the palate.  Finishes with a rotten wooden log of the forest floor bitterness.  It is a very big beer, over the top, well worth it though.  Full bodied, this beer does not play around.

12 oz bottle. Pours a clear dark amber color with a smallish off white head.  Somewhat sweet aroma with scents of toasted malt, caramel, toffe and brown sugar. Flavor is dark fruits with spice. A bit boozy. Medium bodied with good carbonation.
Pours copper/amber.  White head, little retention.  Aroma is sweet caramel and earthy hops.  Taste is syrup sweetness, light bitterness, a strange zip at the end.  Palate is sticky.  Not too bad.

12 oz. bottle poured to my SA Lager glass, displaying a clear, brownish amber color, persistent, brownish tan, bubbles & cream head, and lots of cling to the curtainy lacing. The aroma was light grain, toastiness, light caramel & sweetness, and a slight medicinal wisp. The flavor was similar notes less the wisp, plus a medium, complementary, earthy, hop bitterness with a lingering character to it. The carbonation was nicely situated between soft and lively, the body was medium to full, alcohol was warming, and the finish added pleasant dryness to the lingering bitterness. Well done, amped up NG Alt!

Bottle: pours a dark amber brown color with a great fluffy off white head.  Aroma is malty, sweet, with a nice hint of grapefruit.  Flavor has a nice range of a thick, sweet maltiness with a nice bitter citrus hop flavor.  Nice balance... Syrupy and heavy.  Love it!

Pour is a cola brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is a nice caramel malt.  Flavor is the same.  Nice caramel malts with some earthyness and a alcohol toward the end.  Probably dont need this much alcohol in an alt beer but it has a nice matly backbone.
Bottle. Herbal hops and light caramel malt aroma. Clear brown with a small tan head.  Sweet molasses malt flavor and a harsh bitter finish.

12 ounce bottle, best before August 2012.  Served in a stange/altbier glass, the beer pours a clear reddish/amber color with about an inch light tan head that stayed around for a while.  Theres also a good amount of lacing.  The brew smells like raisins, caramel, toasted malt, and a bit of orange peel.  The taste is mostly like the aroma, but theres also the addition of some molasses and light citrusy and herbal hops.  Mouthfeel/body is medium/full, its a bit syrupy and coating with good carbonation.  I think its a solid overall brew, I enjoyed it.
Bottle from bu11zeyes 10K tasting.  Medium pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is light, tart fruit, alcohol, and caramel.  Similar taste with a nutty finish.
Bottle. This must be a new Sams. Some caramel malt, grapefruit, slight smoke and yeast.  It was ok.
(12oz bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of grain, nuts, raisins, vinous, and caramel.  Flavor of caramel, molasses, raisins, and nuts.

we might as well rob a bank! .. pours a deep brown mahogany .. light foam .. . light booze, brandy, deep lacquered wood, and deep fruit .. . touch of alcohol but o0nly slightly as it warms- great for the 9.3 tag .. . i like this more and more as i drink it! .. well done freddy .. . . i think i hear the nose boy!

This is a bit unfair, as I'm not a huge fan of this style of beer. Overall, the beer has good flavor, and is enjoyable to drink. I would not hesitate to drink another should one present itself.

Bottle.  Pours a clear clean ruby tinged caramel with a small white to beige head.  Quite sweet on the nose, caramel and toffee, toast, and a touch of banana.  Sweet initially, more banana coming through. Medium bodied, caramel and toffee.  Light sweetness with a bit of caramel and malt.  Decent enough; easy drinking and pretty solid for an alt.

Clear bright brown with good sticky light tan head.  Aroma just gets better and better as it warms.   Nice sweet big malty caramel, dark fruits. Smells "purple".  Kinda like a dopplebock.  Flavor didnt do it for me as much.  Sweet almost syrupy upfront, but then turns to an orangepeel and earthy bitterness. Also has a bit of a boozy character.  I do like this beer, but it smells better than it tastes to me.

Out of the 3 varieties in this years LongShot pack, this is the winner for me. You get the impact of the high alcohol content with the classic taste of the Alt style. Derf definitely knows what hes doing here. Hopefully they decide one day to at least make this a seasonal...

Pours a fairly dark brown color with a smallish off white head that dissipates quickly but leaves some sticky lace on the way down. Smell is heavy on the brown sugar and caramel. Hints of almond, ethanol and dark fruit come into play, but this smells like a sweet syrupy mess. Taste is definitely sweet with a bit of an alcohol presence. Syrupy caramel and brown sugar abound with hints of prunes and plums up front. I can feel the alcohol next and long after every sip, it is a bit too present in this beer. Medium to thick body with a light level of carbonation and a sweet sticky syrupy mouthfeel. Im not sure how a 9.3 abv beer can be called an alt, but thats beside the point. This beer is too big, too hot, and too sweet. Reminds me more of a sweet old ale, and might cellar fairly well. If I liked the beer more I would try that.

Light amber? Did they bottle the wrong brew here? This stuffs auburn (and tawny eyes / the kind of eyes that hypnotize me through). Aroma and taste are very sweet, with caramelized sugar, molasses and toffee nearly overpowering the bitter citrus notes.
Pours a deep mahogany, not the light amber the description says. Aroma of alcohol mostly. Almond/ameretto aftertaste. I dont like it much.

12 oz bottle via sixpack from Spirits Crossroads. Poured a good looking clear dark burgundy body with an average sized foamy off white head and lots of rising effervescence. Aroma starts off syrupy sweet with nutty undertones berry skins, cough medicine and wet bread. Flavor is dry with slight sherry notes, alcohol, old stale toffee and bad berries. Super dry palate with a fuller mouthfeel and average to stronger carbonation. Meh not that good except for someone looking to catch a buzz off the monster 9.3% ABV.
Pours brownish amber with a tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Flavor is caramel, brown sugar, some light fruity notes with a good bit of hoppy bitterness.

Bottle @ home. Pours a clear, dark orangish brown appearance with a brown head. A touch cloying, burnt, dark caramel malty, lightly floral hoppy aroma. Fairly cloying and boozy, very rich, sugar, toffee/caramel malty flavor with some fruity elements. Tangy, strong taste. Over the top attempt at an altbier. Derp derp derp.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a nice tan head.  Aroma of caramel malt, dark fruit, brown sugar, and chocolate.  Taste is caramel, molasses, dark fruit, toffee, and alcohol.  A bit sweet for me.  Decent.

A: Pours a rusty copper colored body reminiscent of iced tea. Theres a good bit of clarity considering how (relatively) dark the body is. The head is a two-finger heavy cream color with downright impressive retention and lacing.

S: Note I have little to no experience drinking altbiers, but its dark fruit notes (raisin, plum, fig) combined with the caramel and toffee are very reminiscent of a good dopplebock. Theres also a good deal of both earthiness and zestiness, suggesting this is fairly well hopped.

T/M: Again, lots of caramel and toffee flavor is augmented with raisinesque fruitiness. At first, it reminds me of rum-soaked raisins without the alcohol flavor - quite an impressive accomplishment. Despite its initially heavy feel, the finish is crisp, zesty, and downright refreshing, with the noble hops helping to impart a pleasant dry bitterness on the tongue and the carbonation to help ease it down even more. I think its well balanced and highly drinkable, but not the most complex brew by any stretch.

O: I like this one a lot. Its warming character betrays its refreshing drinkability. I dont have any witty quips about this one, but its another hit from the Longshot pack.
Best 9+% beer ive ever had. Masked the bite well. Smooth but potent. Dark brown, full bodied, malty.

Bottle. Deep copper with medium sized off white sudsy head.  Nose is ho-hum malt, brown sugar, oatmeal, orange peel, lemon, grapefruit.  Flavor big, boozy, burt sugar, roast.  Big bitter finish.  Would be much better at 5.3%

Pours deep clear mahogany with a large soapy tan head.  The aroma has dark berries, toffee, heavily toasted malt, anise and it is overall very full and rich.  Medium / full lush body with quite a bit of carbonation.  The flavor starts out with the aroma traits along with lots of sharp fruitiness and alcohol burn.  The finish is on the astringent side.  There is a raisin aspect as it warms.  Okay alt, but I prefer the lower alcohol alts.

Medium to dark bodied amber in color or more orange than red hues with a duly head. Aromas of banana, citrus hops, spicy, and caramel. Flavors of caramel, light grain, touch of banana, then goes into a citrus/pinelike backbone. More like 65 percent malt  and 35 percent hops on the palate. Sweet, bitter, alcohol mostly hidden, leaves a slight malt and hop bitterness aftertaste.

Pours an amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of caramel malts, dark fruits and some citrus hops.  Flavor is strong of the caramel malts and the dark fruits.  Only a slight hint of the citrus hops.

Deep mahogany brown with a generous frothy tan head that left thick and intricate lace. Toasted malt, nuts, and caramel aromas with a hint of ripe fruit waiting to be fermented into red wine. Flavor profile features the sweetness of the caramel and toasted malts with prominent dark fruit like raisins, dates, and figs. Faint offsetting hops bitterness. Medium body, strong alcohol, minimal carbonation, and a somewhat seet finish.

Big taste. Full body. A real kick ass beer. Nice kick but smooth when it needs to
